sph.event

Class BasicEventManager<E,S,D,L extends EventListener<E,S,D>>

  • java.lang.Object
    • sph.event.BasicEventManager<E,S,D,L>
  • Type Parameters:
    E - the parameterized event type.
    S - the parameterized type of the event source.
    D - the parameterized type of the event data.
    L - the parameterized type of the event listener.
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    Serializable, EventManager<E,S,D,L>

    public class BasicEventManager<E,S,D,L extends EventListener<E,S,D>>
extends Object
implements EventManager<E,S,D,L>, Serializable
    Generic event manager class. Events are of any type. Only the negotiating classes needs to know about the events existence. It is transparent also to the EventManager who only delegates the events.

    Note: great care must be exercised if mutable objects are used as events. The behavior of a map is not specified if the value of an object is changed in a manner that affects equals comparisons while the object is a key in the map.

    A potential problem with string based events are that there might be name conflicts. In a large system, one might consider prefixing the event names to avoid conflicts. If this seems to become a problem, the system is probably bad designed anyway; The number of different event types should be kept low.

    The listener class must implement the EventListener interface which implies the sph.event.EventListener#on(E event, S source, D data) method. The listener class registers itself in the EventManager by: 

     EventManager e = new EventManager();
 e.addListener("EventName", source);
    The source class of the event will call: 
     e.callListeners("EventName", object, data);
    and the EventManager will then call the sph.event.EventListener#on() method of every listener.

    The definition of event, object and data is purely up to the involved classes. Typically object will be the source of the event (the created object for a "Create" event, the deleted object for a "Delete" event and so forth.) The additional data object is for convenience only and will often be null.

    Author:
    Sami Holck
    See Also:
    Serialized Form
